# Hand Guiding (RB 0104) – Updated Ontology Entry

## Academic Context

Hand guiding represents a paradigm shift in human-robot interaction, fundamentally altering how operators interface with industrial automation. Rather than relying on traditional teach pendants or conventional programming languages, hand guiding enables direct physical manipulation of robot arms to establish motion trajectories and waypoints.[1][2] This methodology emerged from collaborative robotics (cobots) development, where safety-monitored force and power limitations permit close human-robot proximity during programming phases.[1]

The technique draws from principles of intuitive human-machine interfaces and leverages force-sensing technology to detect operator intent through physical contact. What distinguishes hand guiding from earlier manual robot manipulation is its integration with safety standards and its capacity to record complex motion patterns automatically.[1][2]

- Academic foundations
  - Rooted in human factors engineering and ergonomic interface design
  - Builds upon force-feedback control systems developed in the 1990s-2000s
  - Aligned with ISO 10218-1 5.10.3 safety standards for collaborative operation[1]
  - Represents democratisation of robot programming, reducing technical barriers to entry

## Current Landscape (2025)

Hand guiding has transitioned from experimental feature to mainstream programming methodology across collaborative robot platforms. The technology now encompasses two primary teaching paradigms: point-based teaching and path-based teaching.[2]

- Point-based teaching methodology
  - Operator guides robot to discrete positions and records waypoints via button press
  - Intuitive for applications requiring sequential positioning (assembly, material handling)
  - Particularly accessible for personnel without formal programming training[2]
  - Rapid deployment capability—complete motion programmes can be generated in hours rather than days

- Path-based teaching methodology
  - Continuous trajectory recording during operator-guided motion
  - Essential for contour-following applications (sanding, polishing, surface finishing)[2]
  - Automatic position generation at preset intervals ensures smooth path interpolation
  - Individual waypoint refinement available post-recording for precision optimisation

- Technical capabilities and operational constraints
  - Speed monitoring enforced at 200 mm/sec maximum during hand-guided operation[1]
  - Force-sensing integration (FANUC FS15iA exemplar) enables responsive, operator-controlled movement[1]
  - Requires physical robot access during programming—inherently an online methodology[3]
  - Robot operates in reduced-velocity safety mode throughout teaching phase[3]
  - Emergency stop functionality mandatory as enabling device[1]

- Industry adoption and implementations
  - FANUC collaborative models with integrated hand guidance systems[1]
  - Yaskawa cobots utilising three-button flange interface for intuitive control[4]
  - KUKA ready2_pilot system with multifunctional Commander attachment[5]
  - Increasingly standard feature across major collaborative robot manufacturers

- UK and North England context
  - Significant adoption within automotive manufacturing clusters (particularly Midlands and North West)
  - Growing implementation in precision engineering sectors across Greater Manchester and Leeds
  - Sheffield-based advanced manufacturing initiatives incorporating hand-guided cobots for tool-making and prototyping
  - Newcastle and Tyne & Wear regions exploring hand guiding for small-to-medium enterprise (SME) automation adoption
  - UK manufacturing bodies increasingly recognising hand guiding as accessibility solution for non-specialist operators

## Distinguishing Hand Guiding from Related Technologies

Hand guiding differs fundamentally from alternative programming approaches, particularly TwinTrack (laser tracker-based offline programming).[3] Whilst both provide intuitive alternatives to conventional programming, hand guiding requires physical robot presence and operates in online mode, whereas TwinTrack enables offline trajectory definition using handheld laser tracker probes without robot access.[3] This distinction carries significant implications for deployment scenarios: hand guiding suits rapid iterative teaching in production environments, whilst TwinTrack accommodates pre-programming before physical robot deployment.

## Research & Literature

The academic literature on hand guiding remains somewhat dispersed, reflecting its relatively recent emergence as standardised practice. Key sources include:

- ISO 10218-1:2011 (amended 2016) – Robots and robotic devices: Safety requirements for industrial robots – Part 1: General requirements. International Organisation for Standardisation. Specifically section 5.10.3 addresses hand-guided operation safety requirements.[1]

- Collaborative robot safety standards and force-limiting specifications documented through International Federation of Robotics (IFR) technical publications and A3 (Association for Advancing Automation) guidance documents on cobot classification and safety-monitored stop functionality.[4][8]

- Practical implementation literature from major manufacturers (FANUC, Yaskawa, KUKA) provides technical specifications and operational guidance, though peer-reviewed academic analysis of hand-guiding efficacy, cognitive load, and long-term operator outcomes remains limited.

- Emerging research directions include: comparative analysis of teaching methodologies (hand guiding versus graphical interfaces versus AI-assisted programming); ergonomic assessment of prolonged hand-guided operation; integration of machine learning to optimise trajectory recording; and standardisation of hand-guiding interfaces across heterogeneous robot platforms.

## UK Context

British manufacturing has embraced hand guiding as a mechanism for democratising automation access, particularly within SME sectors traditionally underserved by conventional robotics. The technology aligns with UK industrial strategy objectives emphasising upskilling and workforce transition.

- North England innovation hubs
  - Manchester: Advanced manufacturing clusters incorporating hand-guided cobots within precision engineering and electronics assembly
  - Leeds: Integration within tool-making and bespoke manufacturing operations
  - Sheffield: Established advanced manufacturing ecosystem leveraging hand guiding for rapid prototyping and small-batch production
  - Newcastle: Emerging adoption within regional manufacturing initiatives targeting SME automation accessibility

- Regional considerations
  - Hand guiding particularly valuable for North England's diverse manufacturing base, where production runs often preclude investment in extensive programming infrastructure
  - Reduces dependency on specialist programmers, addressing regional skills gaps
  - Facilitates knowledge transfer from experienced operators to automated systems

## Future Directions

Hand guiding technology trajectory suggests several developments:

- Integration with artificial intelligence and machine learning
  - Adaptive force-feedback algorithms learning operator preferences
  - Predictive trajectory optimisation based on historical teaching patterns
  - Computer vision integration enabling context-aware motion adjustment

- Standardisation and interface harmonisation
  - Cross-platform hand-guiding protocols reducing manufacturer lock-in
  - Unified safety frameworks simplifying multi-robot environments
  - Gesture recognition and haptic feedback enhancements

- Expanded application domains
  - Complex assembly operations currently requiring specialist programming
  - Collaborative tasks involving simultaneous human-robot manipulation
  - Dynamic task adaptation responding to real-time environmental changes

- Anticipated challenges
  - Operator fatigue and ergonomic considerations during extended hand-guided sessions
  - Precision limitations inherent to manual trajectory definition
  - Safety assurance in increasingly autonomous learning systems
  - Regulatory evolution as hand-guided systems incorporate greater autonomy

---

**Note:** This entry reflects current practice as of November 2025. Hand guiding remains an active area of technical development; practitioners should consult manufacturer documentation and current ISO standards for implementation specifics. The technology's accessibility—requiring neither programming expertise nor formal certification—represents its most significant contribution to manufacturing democratisation, though this accessibility demands rigorous safety protocols and operator training.
